prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We use the coarsest frequency resolution available (31.25 MHz) due to the lack of small-scale velocity features and the desire for the broadest bandwidth. Four 2 GHz wide bands have been set up in the OT for each source. The redshifts are accurate enough that the [CII] line will lie in the observed window. The requested time on source and the total time are 49.4 min and 79.7 min, respectively, thus an efficiency of 62%.

In cycles 0,1 the resolution was about 0.7". Since spatial resolution is not the prime goal, we select the C36-3 configuration, resolution of 0.5" close to the deconvolved [CII] source sizes of the CFHQS detected quasars. Thus, the source may be just about resolved.

The three z~6 CFHQS quasars with black hole (BH) mass ~10^8 M_sun detected with ALMA have a mean flux f(1.2 mm) of 0.11 mJy, which corresponds to a mean far-IR luminosity of 2.7 10^11 L_sun and a mean star formation rate of 47 M_sun /yr. Their [CII] emission linewidths cover the range 190-360 km/s and their mean [CII] emission flux is 0.58 Jy km/s. Their <L_CII/L_FIR> luminosity ration roughly equals 2*10^-3, a value about 4x larger than those for SDSS quasars of M_BH ~ 10^9 M_sun or higher. Measurement of [CII] linewidths is a key science goal. We wish to distinguish between linewidths of FWHM ~ 500 km/s (ratio of black hole to galaxy mass at z = 6 similar to locally) or FWHM ~ 200 km/s (10x higher ratio at high z). For the OT sensitivity calculator and time estimate, we adopt a linewidth of 300 km/s and a sensitivity of 0.3 mJy in a band width of 31.25 MHz or ~35 km/s (mean rms of the measured CFHQS quasar FWHM).

We use the coarsest frequency resolution available (31.25 MHz) due to the lack of small-scale velocity features and the desire for the broadest bandwidth. Four 2 GHz wide bands have been set up in the OT for each source. The redshifts are accurate enough that the [CII] line will lie in the observed window. The requested time on source and the total time are 47.4 min and 76.6 min, respectively, thus an efficiency of 62%.

In cycles 0,1 the resolution was about 0.7". Since spatial resolution is not the prime goal, we select the C36-3 configuration, resolution of 0.5" close to the deconvolved [CII] source sizes of the CFHQS detected quasars. Thus, the source may be just about resolved.

In cycles 0,1 the resolution was about 0.7". Since spatial resolution is not the prime goal, we select the C36-3 configuration, resolution of 0.5" close to the deconvolved [CII] source sizes of the CFHQS detected quasars. Thus, the source may be just about resolved.

Four 2 GHz wide bands have been set up in the OT for each source. The redshifts are accurate enough that the [CII] line will lie in the observed window. In cycles 0,1 the resolution was about 0.7". Since spatial resolution is not the prime goal, we select the C36-3 configuration, resolution of 0.5" close to the deconvolved [CII] source sizes of the CFHQS detected quasars. Thus, the source may be just about resolved.

Their [CII] emission linewidths cover the range 190-360 km/s and their mean [CII] emission flux is 0.58 Jy km/s. Their <L_CII/L_FIR> luminosity ration roughly equals 2*10^-3, a value about 4x larger than those for SDSS quasars of M_BH ~ 10^9 M_sun or higher. Measurement of [CII] linewidths is a key science goal. We wish to distinguish between linewidths of FWHM ~ 500 km/s (ratio of black hole to galaxy mass at z = 6 similar to locally) or FWHM ~ 200 km/s (10x higher ratio at high z). For the OT sensitivity calculator and time estimate, we adopt a linewidth of 300 km/s and a sensitivity of 0.3 mJy in a band width of 31.25 MHz or ~35 km/s (mean rms of the measured CFHQS quasar FWHM).

We use the coarsest frequency resolution available (31.25 MHz) due to the lack of small-scale velocity features and the desire for the broadest bandwidth. Four 2 GHz wide bands have been set up in the OT for each source. The redshifts are accurate enough that the [CII] line will lie in the observed window. The requested time on source and the total time are 44.8 min and 74.0 min, respectively, thus an efficiency of 61%.

In cycles 0,1 the resolution was about 0.7". Since spatial resolution is not the prime goal, we select the C36-3 configuration, resolution of 0.5" close to the deconvolved [CII] source sizes of the CFHQS detected quasars. Thus, the source may be just about resolved.

The three z~6 CFHQS quasars with black hole (BH) mass ~10^8 M_sun detected with ALMA have a mean flux f(1.2 mm) of 0.11 mJy, which corresponds to a mean far-IR luminosity of 2.7 10^11 L_sun and a mean star formation rate of 47 M_sun /yr. Their [CII] emission linewidths cover the range 190-360 km/s and their mean [CII] emission flux is 0.58 Jy km/s. Their <L_CII/L_FIR> luminosity ration roughly equals 2*10^-3, a value about 4x larger than those for SDSS quasars of M_BH ~ 10^9 M_sun or higher. Measurement of [CII] linewidths is a key science goal. We wish to distinguish between linewidths of FWHM ~ 500 km/s (ratio of black hole to galaxy mass at z = 6 similar to locally) or FWHM ~ 200 km/s (10x higher ratio at high z). For the OT sensitivity calculator and time estimate, we adopt a linewidth of 300 km/s and a sensitivity of 0.3 mJy in a band width of 31.25 MHz or ~35 km/s (mean rms of the measured CFHQS quasar FWHM). This quasar (CFHQS J2329-0301) was not detected in cycle 0 at a sensitivity of 0.7 mJy; thus combining old and new data gives a total rms ~ 0.25 mJy so ~3x better than before.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our goal is to understand the evolution of galaxies and black holes at the earliest epoch. We thus propose to observe five z=6.0-6.5 quasars in [CII] and rest-frame 160 micron continuum known to have black hole mass ~10^8 solar masses. The three quasars of this kind already detected with ALMA in [CII] and dust continuum are consistent with the relation [CII] to far-IR (FIR) luminosity ratio versus L_FIR found for bolometric-luminosity matched galaxies at lower z and suggest that L_[CII] can be used a high-redshift star formation estimator, even in the presence of a moderate AGN. Additional, moderately faint z~6 quasars are needed to confirm this behaviour. Our main goal is a comparison of the star formation rate and accretion rate in the context of models for black hole and galaxy evolution in the first billion years since the Big Bang. We also want to confirm the lack of significant offset from the local M_BH versus galaxy velocity dispersion relation of the CFHQS+SDSS z~6 quasar sample and understand the constraints placed on models by this observation combined with the relatively low measured star formation rates.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: cycle 0 The black hole - galaxy mass relationship at redshift 6 PI: C. Willott cycle 1 The black hole - galaxy mass relationship at redshift 6 PI: C. Willott
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
